title: 8 Essential Figma Tips Empower Designers to Build Flexible Branded Templates in Buzz for Team Consistency

paragraphs.content: Figma Buzz enables designers to publish internal branded templates that allow cross-functional teams to create on-brand assets like social posts and ads without breaking layouts. The official Figma blog outlines eight key tips, including using Auto Layout for responsiveness and separating text layers for Bulk Create compatibility with CSV/XLSX imports. These practices ensure templates adapt to varying content while maintaining brand standards, as demonstrated in Figma's publishing tutorials.

paragraphs.content: Descriptive layer naming, such as "Event Title" or "CTA Button Text," with example text like "Date of Event (e.g. July 10, 2025)," guides users and prevents formatting issues. Component variants from Figma Design systems let marketers swap layouts or toggle elements without exposing raw designs. This approach supports scalable asset creation across campaigns, aligning with Buzz's focused editing mode.

sections.title: Mastering Auto Layout and Layer Separation for Responsive Templates

paragraphs.content: Auto Layout ensures components like buttons and text boxes maintain spacing when content lengths change, preventing misalignment in templates. Designers must separate text layers for each unique input to enable reliable Bulk Create mapping and preserve formatting during imports. Testing with realistic content verifies that designs accommodate variations without distortion.

paragraphs.content: Locking brand elements like logos while leaving body text and images editable provides strategic control in Buzz templates. Pink outlines and lock icons signal restrictions, limiting edits to designated fields via the Edit Content panel. Comprehensive template sets for campaigns, such as Instagram posts and stories, enhance usability across formats.

sections.title: Leveraging Component Variants and Organization for Discoverability

paragraphs.content: Component variants allow swaps for logos, icons, or layouts, combining options into one set to reduce template proliferation. Publishing connects templates to design systems, exposing properties like toggles for on/off elements in Buzz. Clear file titles, standardized naming, and logical groupings improve visibility in the template picker.
